Award.AbstractNarration:
Mazur proposes to work on the statistical and algorithmic aspects of number theory---specifically as related to elliptic curves, abelian varieties, modular curves, and automorphic forms. For example, he is engaged in a research program with Karl Rubin to investigate the Markovian statistics of Selmer groups of quadratic twist families of elliptic curves. Selmer groups provide a delicate---and computable---gauge for the arithmetic of elliptic curves and abelian varieties. A close understanding of Selmer groups can be applied to questions as far-ranging as issues of solvability and unsolvability (Hilbert?s Tenth Problem) or refined analytic formulas (where Rubin and the PI have solved a good part of a conjecture of Darmon). Mazur also proposes to continue the study of p-adic interpolation of modular eigenforms and of their L-functions.

In broad terms, Mazur wants to understand polynomial equations and the algorithms that might lead us to the solutions of such equations. It is vastly instructive to study such solutions, both specifically and statistically, bringing the relevant analytic and arithmetic tools to bear on the problem. Such investigations have had, in the past, surprisingly broader application---both practical and theoretical---as the PI hopes will be the case in this instance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the major problems in number theory is to understand in as much de- tail as possible the nature and structure of systems of polynomial equations with rational coefficients and more specifically to determine, as explicitly as possible, their solutions. Such problems have applications in number theory (as would be natural) but also in some very applied subjects with implications far beyond the realm of pure mathematics. Cryptography is often mentioned as a direction of application—and cryptography itself has ever broadening importance.

One aspect of that mission is in the direction of arithmetic statistics. The expectation—becoming more and more convincing—is that many (important) sys- tems of polynomial equations do not have many solutions. Much recent work has gone into this, and the project 1302409 is largely about this theme. One goal is to understand the extent to which a system of polynomial equations acquires no new solutions even if one extends the number field in which one seeks to solve that system! Such a phenomenon is signaled by the phrase i bf Diophantine Stable. The major outcome of the project 1302409 consists in new results (joint with Karl Ru- bin) establishing Diophantine Stability in a wide range of contexts, in developing a heuristic that predicts statistics for the occurrence of Diophantine Stability, and in obtaining striking computational data confirming those statistics.
